column4: I think I smeared some Artic Silver thermal compound on my motherboard where it shouldn't be.  Can I clean the motherboard with isopryl alcohol and a lint free cloth?  Or, is that dangerous?

I've also got this new ArctiClean "thermal material remover" that you're supposed to use on CPU's, anybody know *for sure* if I can use that on my motherboard?  It does a much better job than isopryl alcohol, at least it did on the CPU.
I second that, definitely don't use it
sky_monkey00: thanks, I'm doing it the hard way with isopryl.  Thanks guys.
if you understand the risks, back up your repository state and go for it.
well, actually i'm wondering if nalioth isn't right, i already can't find the hot-babe package they claim on their web page to have in there
I tend towards the conservative and, personally, I'd prefer to install from source rather than use an unofficial repository
of course if you back up you can revert, but why risk your package database state, even if the risk is small?
nalioth: yeah, i'll just compile, thanks guys
ls?  I don't know, you have to press two different keys ...
and you have to press the l first
kind of tough  :)
you are installing a kernel module.  kernel modules must be built for a specific kernel.
thanks
but, it makes me a little leary of installing it now...
yes, it could certainly happen.
why does upgrading the graphics card make business graphics faster? I'm still trying to figure this out.
business graphics are still graphcis.  If you dramatically improve the performance of modifying what's on the screen, then things go faster.
the card can move video data much more quickly.

k, thanks.  I didn't know business graphics did any real work on the graphics card, i thought the CPU just told the video card what pixels to render, and the video card did it.  Have never read about 2D video card features, have only heard about 3D ones
but then don't you get a huge headache when you want one little thing to work?
no
at least, not so far
